Award.AwardTitle: CNH: Diversification, Portfolio Effects, and the Sustainability of Fishing Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
It has become increasingly apparent that biological complexity stabilizes many key ecosystem processes and increases the reliability of resource flows to humans. While discussed extensively in the ecological literature, the extent to which biocomplexity translates into tangible social and economic benefits to communities and their economies remains essentially unexplored. Our research will investigate how the biocomplexity of fisheries ecosystems translates into social and economic attributes of the human communities that exploit these ecosystems. Because human activities often feed back to affect the biocomplexity of ecosystems, we will further explore how human effects on the inherent variability of ecosystems affect the socio-economics of human communities. By coupling our understanding of how biocomplexity affects humans, and how human actions affect natural system biocomplexity, we will be in a position to inform efficient biocomplexity policy. While the methods, design, and results of this research program will be genera1izable across a range of coupled human and natural systems, we focus on the salmon-producing ecosystems of Western Alaska where we have extensive knowledge of the natural biocomplexity of the ecosystems, where the regional socio economic activities are supported almost exclusively by fisheries, and where tight feedbacks exist between natural and human components of the ecosystems. These features make these particular systems highly tractable to integrated bioeconomic assessment and modeling.

We seek to understand the interactions between the ecological dynamics of salmon ecosystems and the social and economic benefits to people who rely on salmon for their livelihoods in Western Alaska. In particular we are interested in understanding how the reliability of annual salmon returns, as determined by the biocomplexity of salmon stocks and their watersheds, affects the long-term economic performance of fisheries and the ability of local residents to participate salmon fisheries. We will also explore how management strategies should change as multiple ecosystem objectives are included into policy. In particular, current management objectives are focused narrowly on maximizing biological yield to commercial fisheries without consideration for the ecological and associated economic benefits of salmon in freshwater ecosystems (e.g., via sport fishing). Further, we will assess the degree to which fishermen and their communities benefit from the opportunity to generalize their efforts to exploit multiple species and multiple ecosystems as an alternative to the specialization that current management systems tend to encourage. This work will provide key insights into the complex interactions between social-economic dynamics and the ecological dynamics of fisheries and other coupled natural-human ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ecosystems are inherently complex systems, organized by variation in their physical characteristics, in their biological attributes expressed both among and within species, and in the characteristics of the human communities that are intrinsically part of them. All of these features also interact with one other and with the overriding climate in surprising and poorly understood ways. Human systems often benefit from more reliable (less variable) flows of natural resources when their harvesting integrates across complexity in ecosystems, for example, by harvesting many different species of fish, or by harvesting resources at many different places in an ecosystem. In this project we explored and quantified some of the social and economic values of this reliability in resource flows that are produced from complexity in ecosystems. We made several important discoveries through this project. One important result, based on an analysis of a large dataset tracking fishing revenues to Alaskan communities over the last four decades, was that the diversity of resources a community exploits controls how vulnerable it is to large-scale changes in marine ecosystems. Communities that are highly specialized are very vulnerable to change in the ocean while those that are diversified show little response to changing ocean conditions.

We also explored the possibilities for economic benefits that derive from coordinated exploitation of predators and prey in salmon-producing ecosystems. This analysis showed that exploiting predators can increase the production of prey species, but that the economic benefits to people were strongly constrained by their roles in the fishing industry. Fishers nearly always benefit when exploiting both predators and their prey, while the seafood processing sector only realizes additional revenues when their costs are small or when the effect of predators on prey abundance is very strong. This result emphasizes the variation in economic benefits that flow to different people under the same management regime, a phenomenon rarely considered in bio-economics.

Other dimensions of our work considered the ecological trade-offs in allocating salmon to commercial fisheries versus allowing them to spawn in watersheds where they become a key part of aquatic and terrestrial food webs. This trade-off has become politically charged along the North American west coast because salmon play important ecological roles in watersheds that could be diminished if too many salmon are caught in marine commercial fisheries. Our analyses demonstrate that the abundance of salmon released to watersheds to maximize yield to commercial fisheries actually matches well with the salmon abundances needed to saturate their ecological roles in watersheds. This information suggests that the debate regarding whether commercial fisheries are ‘starving’ watersheds of salmon-derived resources is likely moot, and that management designed to maximize watershed processes actually aligns closely with management designed to maximize harvest in commercial fisheries.

Last, we developed theory to show that the stability of year-to-year fish abundance can have tangible economic benefits to the fishing industry. Reliability in catches enables seafood processing companies to increase their revenues in many circumstances because it is easier to invest in and develop the precise amount of capacity for efficiently processing fish, if future abundances are reliable from year to year. Thus, when placing economic values on the revenues generated from fishery ecosystems, it is important to consider both how variable a resource is, in addition to its long-term average production, which is typically the focus of such assessments.

By communicating our results to the fishing industry, to decision-makers, and to the public, we have provided new perspectives about the values of naturally complex ecosystems, and the potential amplification of risks that are produced through simplification of ecosystems. In salmon-producing watersheds around the Pacific Rim, these risks are manifested as increased volatility in year-to-year returns of salmon. Even in places where the average number of fish that are harvested can be maintained, volatility in fish abundance places distinct social and economic constraints on people. In communities that can diversify across many species, much of the year-to-year volatility in economic value from fishing disappears and, in fact, can protect community economies from large-scale changes in the ocean in response to climate change.
